Red Sox Foundation named Behavioral Health and Developmental Services (dba Community Partners) as one of the five finalists in New Hampshire eligible to win the $10,000 IMPACT Award grant this year! This year’s IMPACT Awards focuses on organizations that have demonstrated an impact on raising awareness and improving mental health outcomes in their community. In 2019, Community Partners assisted 2,600 individual with continued therapy, assisted students in 20 different area schools, and case managers assisted over 4,000 families. We also were the driving force behind the Dover Mental Health Alliance to reduce the stigma around mental health, an initiative that hopes to roll out to surrounding communities.

The award is based on how many people show their support by voting for us. The Organization with the most votes will win a $10,000 grant from the Red Sox Foundation! Please show us your support and help us win by voting at www.redsox.com/IMPACT. You are allowed to vote once every day (including weekends) up through June 22.

shared_text:
Dover Public Library
April 27 at 11:48 AM ·

Send a photo of your creation to p.falconer@dover.nh.gov and we will share it for you!

At Home Creation Station
Circle Art

You will need:
* a piece of paper
* pens, pencils, crayons, markers
* circle shapes to trace (any jar lids, coffee can lids, rolls of duct tape, masking tape, paper cups, or other circle shapes will work)

Directions:
1. Trace circle shapes with a pen or marker. You can trace the same circle shape over and over for your project or trace different size circles. To add interest, overlap circles. You can make as many or as few as you’d like in this circle project.

2. Now it’s time to color with crayons, markers, colored pencils, or paint. You can use as many or as few colors as you like, create patterns, stay in circles, or color outside of them. There’s no right or wrong way to color your circle art! Just have fun!

post_text: Don't miss your opportunity to join us today for a great cause! Empty Bowls is a national grassroots effort to help fight hunger. Mrs. Calhoun and Principal Lynde's 8th Grade Advisory ,in partnership with a great group of 5th graders organized by Mrs. Lent, have created what is known as the Snack Shack. The idea behind the Snack Shack is to try to reduce the amount of edible food that is thrown out and provide snacks and drinks for students who may need a little more at lunch.
The students have set up a table in the cafeteria at Dover Middle School with 3 bins on it; one for fruit, one for drinks and one for pre-packaged snacks. Any student who has left overs that fit into one of these categories, may leave their snack/drink in one of the bins. Then, any student who may still be hungry/thirsty at lunch time, may take an item from the bins. The students will also be monitoring the bins for the first week to help explain the process. Leftovers will be brought to the nurse's office at the end of each day.

post_text: We would like to address a situation that came to our attention over the past 24 hours and let the Dover School District community know we are working with students and educators diligently at DHS to investigate and address this incident of extreme racial insensitivity. Families and school community members will be updated as we create opportunities to come together and discuss, process, and plan as a community to address both the immediate situation and long-term implications of racial insensitivity and implicit bias.
